verses.text: Now this is the commandment—the statutes and the rules—that the LORD your God commanded me to teach you, so that you may do them in the land that you are crossing over to possess,
verses.comment: “Statutes and rules” is a literal translation of the Hebrew words chukim and mishpatim.

verses.text: so that you may fear the LORD your God, you, your son, and your grandson, by keeping all His statutes and His commandments, which I command you, all the days of your life, and so that your days may be prolonged.
verses.comment: “You, your son, and your grandson” renders the Hebrew literally; meaning entire generations.

verses.text: Hear, therefore, O Israel, and be careful to do them, so that it may go well with you, and that you may multiply greatly, as the LORD, the God of your fathers, has promised you, in a land flowing with milk and honey.
verses.comment: "Milk and honey" is a Hebrew idiom kept literally.

verses.text: Hear, O Israel: The LORD our God, the LORD is one.
verses.comment: The Shema. Literal translation of the Hebrew: 'YHWH our God, YHWH one.'

verses.text: And you shall love the LORD your God with all your heart, and with all your soul, and with all your strength.
verses.comment: "Heart...soul...strength" is a literal rendering; see also NT quotations.

verses.text: And these words that I command you today shall be on your heart.
verses.comment: Phrase 'on your heart' is a literal translation.

verses.text: You shall teach them diligently to your children, and you shall speak of them when you sit in your house, and when you walk along the way, and when you lie down, and when you rise.
verses.comment: "Teach diligently" literally means to repeat or impress upon.

verses.text: You shall bind them as a sign on your hand, and they shall be as frontlets between your eyes.
verses.comment: "Frontlets" refers to phylacteries; translation is literal.

verses.text: And you shall write them on the doorposts of your house and on your gates.
verses.comment: "Doorposts" refers to 'mezuzot' in Hebrew, kept literal.

verses.text: And it shall be, when the LORD your God brings you into the land He swore to your fathers—to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob—to give you, with great and good cities that you did not build,
verses.comment: The Hebrew follows the same list 'Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.'

verses.text: and houses full of all good things that you did not fill, and wells dug that you did not dig, and vineyards and olive trees that you did not plant, and when you eat and are full,
verses.comment: Lists specific blessings fulfilling God’s promise.

verses.text: then beware, lest you forget the LORD, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of slavery.
verses.comment: "House of slavery" is a literal translation of the Hebrew.

verses.text: You shall fear the LORD your God and serve Him, and you shall swear by His name.
verses.comment: Swearing by God’s name refers to oath-taking; literal.

verses.text: You shall not go after other gods, of the gods of the peoples who are around you,
verses.comment: "Go after" is a literal rendering; it means to follow or serve.

verses.text: for the LORD your God in your midst is a jealous God, lest the anger of the LORD your God be kindled against you, and He destroy you from off the face of the earth.
verses.comment: "Jealous God" is a literal translation; see also Exod. 20:5.

verses.text: You shall not test the LORD your God, as you tested Him at Massah.
verses.comment: Massah refers to Exod. 17:7, 'testing' God by doubting Him.

verses.text: You shall diligently keep the commandments of the LORD your God, and His testimonies, and His statutes, which He has commanded you.
verses.comment: "Testimonies" translates the Hebrew 'edot.'

verses.text: And you shall do what is right and good in the sight of the LORD, so that it may go well with you, and that you may go in and possess the good land that the LORD swore to give to your fathers,
verses.comment: Literal: 'right and good.'

verses.text: by driving out all your enemies from before you, as the LORD has spoken.
verses.comment: God's promised action in Canaan.

verses.text: When your son asks you in time to come, 'What is the meaning of the testimonies and the statutes and the rules that the LORD our God has commanded you?'
verses.comment: Literal: 'in time to come' (Hebrew 'tomorrow' as an idiom for the future).

verses.text: then you shall say to your son, 'We were Pharaoh’s slaves in Egypt, and the LORD brought us out of Egypt with a mighty hand.'
verses.comment: "Mighty hand" is literal.

verses.text: And the LORD showed signs and wonders, great and severe, against Egypt, against Pharaoh, and against all his household, before our eyes.
verses.comment: "Great and severe" is literal.

verses.text: And He brought us out from there, so that He might bring us in and give us the land that He swore to our fathers.
verses.comment: "He might bring us in" is literal.

verses.text: And the LORD commanded us to do all these statutes, to fear the LORD our God, for our good always, so that He might preserve us alive, as we are today.
verses.comment: "For our good always" is a literal phrase.

verses.text: And it will be righteousness for us if we are careful to do all this commandment before the LORD our God, as He has commanded us.
verses.comment: "Righteousness for us" is a literal translation of the Hebrew construction.
